subject: Re: [junit] @BeforeClass throws NullPointerException
msgSnippet: ... And the @BeforeClass and @AfterClass annotations don t solve this how exactly? There isn t anything wrong with static data, you know. ... Except that
messageBody:
On 9/30/05, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> The fact remains that even JUnit users want to reuse data across methods.
> I'm not talking about dependencies, just about resources that are created at
> the beginning of the class and freed at the end.

And the @BeforeClass and @AfterClass annotations don't solve this how
exactly? There isn't anything wrong with static data, you know.

> I sympathize with the effort of keeping test methods in isolation of each
> other, but if this state is read-only and that test methods are idempotent
> (can be run in any order), then this state is not really "evil" in terms of
> unit testing.

Except that read-only and idempotent require programmer discipline.
Using a single instance means that the writer of the tests is required
to be careful to ensure isolation, rather than having the framework
enforce it.

Having shared data be static helps it to stand out - it makes it very
clear what is per-instance data and what is common data.

> It's too bad that JUnit3 (and JUnit4 it seems) will continue to ignore this
> need.

It's not that they ignore the need, Cedric - it's just that there is a
different solution. There is more than one right way to do things, you
know.
